soc.game

Class SOCResourceSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.game.SOCResourceSet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, ResourceSet

    public class SOCResourceSet
extends java.lang.Object
implements ResourceSet, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    This represents a collection of clay, ore, sheep, wheat, and wood resources. Unknown resources are also tracked here. Although it's possible to store negative amounts of resources, it's discouraged.
    See Also:
    SOCResourceConstants, SOCPlayingPiece.getResourcesToBuild(int), Serialized Form

      • getAmounts

        public int[] getAmounts(boolean withUnknown)
        How many resources of each type are contained in the set? (SOCResourceConstants.CLAY, ORE, SHEEP, WHEAT, WOOD)
        Parameters:
        withUnknown - If true, also include the amount of SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN resources
        Returns:
        the amounts of each known resource in the set, starting with SOCResourceConstants.CLAY at index 0, up to WOOD at 4. If withUnknown, index 5 is the amount of SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN.
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        getAmount(int), isEmpty(), SOCResourceSet(int[])

      • getResourceTypeCount

        public int getResourceTypeCount()
        Get the number of known resource types contained in this set: SOCResourceConstants.CLAY to SOCResourceConstants.WOOD, excluding SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN or SOCResourceConstants.GOLD_LOCAL. An empty set returns 0, a set containing only wheat returns 1, that same set after adding wood and sheep returns 3, etc.
        Specified by:
        getResourceTypeCount in interface ResourceSet
        Returns:
        The number of resource types in this set with nonzero resource counts.
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        isEmpty()

        Parameters:

      • add

        public void add(int amt,
                int rtype)
        add an amount to a resource
        Parameters:
        rtype - the type of resource, like SOCResourceConstants.CLAY or SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN
        amt - the amount; if below 0 (thus subtracting resources), the subtraction occurs and no special action is taken. subtract(int, int) takes special action in some cases.

      • subtract

        public boolean subtract(int amt,
                        int rtype)
        subtract an amount from a resource.

        If we're subtracting more from a known resource than there are of that resource, sets that resource to 0, then takes the "excess" away from this set's SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN resources. As a result, UNKNOWN field may be less than 0 afterwards.

        To convert all known resources to UNKNOWN when subtracting an UNKNOWN rtype, call subtract(int, int, boolean) instead.

        Parameters:
        rtype - the type of resource, like SOCResourceConstants.CLAY or SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN
        amt - the amount; unlike in add(int, int), any amount that takes the resource below 0 is treated specially.

      • subtract

        public boolean subtract(int amt,
                        int rtype,
                        boolean asUnknown)
        Subtract an amount from a resource.

        In theory, every player (i.e. robot) knows about all the cards in other players' hands by tracking resources from dice rolls. Any resources obtained through "secret" means (e.g. robbery) are stored as SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN types.

        If we're subtracting more of a known resource than there are of that resource, sets that resource to 0, then takes the "excess" amount away from this set's SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN resources. The number of unknown resources should never be less than zero; that means we've screwed up the count somehow.

        Should unknowns become less than zero we should probably reset the count by asking the server for a total count from this player, subtract the count of known resources, then storing the remainder as unknowns.

        If asUnknown is true and we're subtracting an UNKNOWN rtype, converts this set's known resources to UNKNOWN before subtraction by calling convertAllToUnknown().

        Parameters:
        rtype - the type of resource, like SOCResourceConstants.CLAY or SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN
        amt - the amount; unlike in add(int, int), any amount that takes the resource below 0 is treated specially
        asUnknown - If true and subtracting SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN, calls convertAllToUnknown() first
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • add

        public void add(SOCResourceSet toAdd)
        add an entire resource set's amounts into this set.
        Parameters:
        toAdd - the resource set

      • subtract

        public void subtract(ResourceSet toReduce)
        subtract an entire resource set.

        Loops for each resource type in toReduce, including SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN. If any type's amount would go below 0, clips it to 0. Treats UNKNOWN no differently than the known types.

        To instead subtract such "excess" amounts from this set's UNKNOWN field like subtract(int, int, boolean) does, call subtract(ResourceSet, boolean).

        Parameters:
        toReduce - the resource set to subtract

      • subtract

        public void subtract(ResourceSet toReduce,
                     boolean asUnknown)
        subtract an entire resource set.

        If asUnknown is true:

        • If subtracting SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN, first converts this set's known resources to UNKNOWN by calling convertAllToUnknown().
        • Loops for each resource type in toReduce, including SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN. If any known type's amount would go below 0, clips it to 0 and subtracts the "excess" from the UNKNOWN field, which can become less than 0.
        If false, behaves like subtract(ResourceSet).
        Parameters:
        toReduce - the resource set to subtract
        asUnknown - If true: Removes excess amounts from this set's SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN field instead of clipping to 0; if subtracting UNKNOWN, calls this.convertAllToUnknown() first
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • gte

        boolean gte(ResourceSet other)
        Parameters:
        other - the other SOCResourceSet that is less than or equal to this one.
        Returns:
        true if this SOCResourceSet has a greater count of every type resource than the other set, or if the other set is null. If we have a negative unknown count (which should never happen) assume that our unknowns are larger.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Human-readable form of the set, with format "clay=5|ore=1|sheep=0|wheat=0|wood=3|unknown=0"
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a human readable longer form of the set

      • toShortString

        public java.lang.String toShortString()
        Human-readable form of the set, with format "Resources: 5 1 0 0 3 0". Order of types is Clay, ore, sheep, wheat, wood, unknown.
        Returns:
        a human readable short form of the set
        See Also:
        toFriendlyString()

      • toFriendlyString

        public java.lang.String toFriendlyString()
        Human-readable form of the set, with format "5 clay,1 ore,3 wood". Unknown resources aren't mentioned.
        Returns:
        a human readable longer form of the set; if the set is empty, return the string "nothing".
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        toShortString()

      • toFriendlyString

        public boolean toFriendlyString(java.lang.StringBuffer sb)
        Human-readable form of the set, with format "5 clay, 1 ore, 3 wood". Unknown resources aren't mentioned.
        Parameters:
        sb - Append into this buffer.
        Returns:
        true if anything was appended, false if sb unchanged (this resource set is empty).
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        toFriendlyString()

      • contains

        public boolean contains(ResourceSet other)
        Does this set contain all resources of another set?
        Specified by:
        contains in interface ResourceSet
        Parameters:
        other - the subset to test against; can be null for an empty resource subset
        Returns:
        true if this contains at least the resource amounts in other for each known resource type and SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN. True if other is null or empty.
        See Also:
        contains(int[])

      • contains

        public boolean contains(int[] other)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Does this set contain all resources of another set?
        Parameters:
        other - resource set to test against, of length 5 (clay, ore, sheep, wheat, wood) or 6 (with unknown), or null for an empty resource subset.
        Returns:
        true if this set contains at least the resource amounts in other for each of its resource types. True if other is null or empty.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a non-null other's length is not 5 or 6
